awd_titl_txt: CAREER:  Foundations and Extensions of Public Key Cryptography
awd_abstract_narration:
Increasingly, both personal  and enterprise data are being stored at third-party locations, outside of the data owner's control. A company might directly outsource its data storage by using a backup service such as Amazon's S3 application. In other cases, outsourcing is a by-product of a larger service; for example, several corporations use Salesforce to manage their customer relations and sales data.  Outsourcing data storage offers several benefits:  storage costs can be amortized by a third-party over several customers, a third party can store data at different geographic locations for robustness, and integration with larger application services becomes easier. One can imagine a not too distant future where most computation and storage is realized in a network "cloud". In order to protect data stored at third party services we will need to encrypt it.

Unfortunately, traditional encryption systems are insufficient for these applications. Solving this problem requires an entirely new way of encrypting data. To see this, recall that in traditional public key encryption a party encrypts data to a single known user. While this functionality is useful for applications such as encrypted email and establishing secure web sessions, it lacks the expressiveness needed for more advanced data sharing. In enterprise settings, a party will want to share data with groups of users based on their credentials.  Often a party sharing data will not know which individual users will need to have access to it; moreover, some users will not even exist in the system at the time the data is encrypted. For example, a traveling sales representative might want to encrypt records so that any current or future manager in the personal electronics division can access them.

The proposed research is laying the foundations for an entirely different vision for encryption called Functional Encryption. Instead of encrypting to individual users, in a functional encryption system, one can embed any access predicate f() into the ciphertext itself. Functional encryption simultaneously renders completely general functionality and its data access is self-enforcing --- requiring no trusted mediator.  The PI aims to create a system where the encrypting party can specify any access predicate over a recipient's credentials (i.e.  f can be any Turing Machine). Functional encryption for any predicate opens up a world of possibilities for data sharing; one could encrypt an image such that the access function f encoded an image recognition program allowing only people in the picture to view it.

In addition to broadening our view of public key cryptography, the PI will explore fundamental problems in public key encryption.  One direction is to attempt to build chosen ciphertext secure encryption from standard public key encryption.  Finally, the PI will explore the foundations of building public key cryptography.

por.por_cntn:
Traditionally cryptography and encryption in particular has been viewed as a a way to encode data into a ciphertext such that one particular recipient holding a private key can decrypt it. At the same time the plain data should not be readable by anyone other than the intended recipient. 

While this traditional notion of encryption has served us well for many applications such as point to point communication, for many other applications this notion of encryption is too rigid. For example, suppose that we wanted to base access control on a policy over the user's attributes as opposed to targeting a specific user? Or instead suppose that we wanted to encrypt a program where we give the holder the ability to evaluate the program, but hide the internal implementation of it? This project explores a new area of computing on encrypted data and its applications. We highlight some of its key scientific outcomes below. 

 

Functional Encryption: In a functional encryption system an authority will give the user a secret key corresponding to a function f. If a message m is encrypted the secret key holder can apply their key to learn the output f(m), but not learn anything more than this. For example, I might want to delegate to a server the ability to run a function that determines if an encrypted message is determined to be spam or not. If the message is spam (as determined by a program p) the server should discard the message; however, it should be able to determine this without having the capability to read my encrypted messages.

One key outcome of this project was the first general candidate for functional encryption systems. Prior to that we achieved multiple other results for partial functionality.

 

Code Obfuscation: The goal of code obfuscation is to be able to take a program P and compile it into a program P'. The program P' should be functionally equivalent to P in that for any input x we have that P(x) = P'(x). In addition, the obfuscation should hide the design of the original program to the strongest extent possible. Early attempts at code obfuscation were mainly of a heuristic nature and not based on mathematically sound principles. Our research provided the first general purpose obfuscation candidate. In addition, my research showed how a weaker notion of obfuscation called Indistinguishability Obfuscation could be used to build most of cryptography and made initial progress toward proving it secure under standard assumptions.

 

 

There have been multiple outreach efforts as part of this project. We overview a few here.

 

Voting Systems in Travis County: The PI, Brent Waters, worked as part of an study group on the security machines in Travis County. The report concluded that the current machines should eventually be replaced. Dr. Waters was the only member from a computer science department at an academic institution and was instrumental in reaching this conclusion. This contribution was recognized as part of his NSF PECASE award. 

Undergraduate Research: Dr. Waters lead an outreach effort to include undergraduate students into graduate level research. Two of the three students in the group were female and one of these is going on to pursue a Ph.D.

Modified by: Brent Waters
